content.raw:
Note: I think this PR is probably somewhat on hold as we figure out whether we want to fork ODE or use the upstream version.

But if we want to move ahead with this work as being an illustrative prototype, we could merge it and then revise things later when we make the decision about how to handle ODE.

The upstream ODE dependency of this PR is optional anyhow, so merging this wouldn't really be a burden for anyone.
content.html:
Note: I think this PR is probably somewhat on hold as we figure out whether we want to fork ODE or use the upstream version.

But if we want to move ahead with this work as being an illustrative prototype, we could merge it and then revise things later when we make the decision about how to handle ODE.

The upstream ODE dependency of this PR is optional anyhow, so merging this wouldn't really be a burden for anyone.

pull_request.title: Create a Buggy plugin using ODE to demonstrate the buggyDemo

update.description:
1. This requires ODE install locally, I used ODE 0.15.1 tarball installation
2. The buggyDemo is from ODE [here](https://bitbucket.org/odedevs/ode/src/d0ec00dc230099e9a3fe3bb0f42cc09320b9e1b4/ode/demo/demo_buggy.cpp?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default).  
3. All the `drawstuff` related features are removed from the demo in this PR    
4. More test on orientation of the buggy will be added   
5. This is test against the 2 branches`DllManagement` and `PluginPtrSemantics` of `ign-common` and both passed.   
6. `MathConversions.hh` is more like a naive hard-code tool to make the test run.

pull_request.title: Create a Buggy plugin using ODE to demonstrate the buggyDemo

pullrequest.title: Create a Buggy plugin using ODE to demonstrate the buggyDemo

content.raw:
A possible alternative to embedding the different body poses as their own types would be to add an interface to the plugin which can convert from a body name (string) to a body index (integer). You could then query the plugin for the indices of each of the bodies based on their names, and then use the standard output data (`WorldPoses`) to read the poses of the bodies that you're interested in.

A big part of my motivation behind embedding the end effector pose as a data type in the DART example was to demonstrate the flexibility of CompositeData by giving it a non-standard data type. Here it might be valuable to show that custom data types aren't necessarily needed since you could just use the standard `WorldPoses` to get the pose data.

I think in the final design of the physics engine plugin concept, we'll want a plugin interface that can map from body names to body indices anyway, so this might be a good chance to explore what that interface may look like.

To be clear, this comment is just a suggestion; I wouldn't have any problem with leaving this the way it is.
content.html:
A possible alternative to embedding the different body poses as their own types would be to add an interface to the plugin which can convert from a body name (string) to a body index (integer). You could then query the plugin for the indices of each of the bodies based on their names, and then use the standard output data (WorldPoses) to read the poses of the bodies that you're interested in.

A big part of my motivation behind embedding the end effector pose as a data type in the DART example was to demonstrate the flexibility of CompositeData by giving it a non-standard data type. Here it might be valuable to show that custom data types aren't necessarily needed since you could just use the standard WorldPoses to get the pose data.

I think in the final design of the physics engine plugin concept, we'll want a plugin interface that can map from body names to body indices anyway, so this might be a good chance to explore what that interface may look like.

To be clear, this comment is just a suggestion; I wouldn't have any problem with leaving this the way it is.

content.raw:
At some point we discussed the matter of whether it's necessary to call `ResetQueries` before `WriteRequiredData`. If we stick with the current query concept (or something similar), I think what we should do is ensure that the `ignition-physics` pipeline always calls `ResetQueries` on each of the `CompositeData` objects *before* passing them to `ForwardStep::Step(~)` so that the developer of the plugin does not need to be concerned about the concept of the "queried state". That way the `ignition-physics` pipeline can identify which data types are (or are not) being handled without the plugin developer needing to give any thought to the queried states.

I'm still completely open to a redesign of the "queried" concept, so long as we can have a sensible way of recognizing whenever some type of data is being neglected by the plugin that's supposed to be handling it.
content.html:
At some point we discussed the matter of whether it's necessary to call ResetQueries before WriteRequiredData. If we stick with the current query concept (or something similar), I think what we should do is ensure that the ignition-physics pipeline always calls ResetQueries on each of the CompositeData objects before passing them to ForwardStep::Step(~) so that the developer of the plugin does not need to be concerned about the concept of the "queried state". That way the ignition-physics pipeline can identify which data types are (or are not) being handled without the plugin developer needing to give any thought to the queried states.

I'm still completely open to a redesign of the "queried" concept, so long as we can have a sensible way of recognizing whenever some type of data is being neglected by the plugin that's supposed to be handling it.

pull_request.title: Create a Buggy plugin using ODE to demonstrate the buggyDemo

pullrequest.title: Create a Buggy plugin using ODE to demonstrate the buggyDemo

content.raw: In the ODE example, some cleanup functions are called before the end of `main`, like `dGeomDestroy`, `dJointGroupDestroy`, `dSpaceDestroy`, etc. It might be a good idea to call those in the destructor of the plugin to make sure we avoid memory leaks. I think repeated loading and unloading of this plugin type would leak the memory of those objects.
content.html: In the ODE example, some cleanup functions are called before the end of main, like dGeomDestroy, dJointGroupDestroy, dSpaceDestroy, etc. It might be a good idea to call those in the destructor of the plugin to make sure we avoid memory leaks. I think repeated loading and unloading of this plugin type would leak the memory of those objects.

content.raw:
Tried with ` sudo apt-get install libode-dev `, which will install ode version of `0.13.1`    
The `dJointSetHinge2Axes` function is not defined.    
For now, compile ODE > 0.15.1 from source and install is the only way to test out this plugin
content.html:
Tried with sudo apt-get install libode-dev, which will install ode version of 0.13.1
The dJointSetHinge2Axes function is not defined.
For now, compile ODE > 0.15.1 from source and install is the only way to test out this plugin
